content: Hi! My name is Rebecka and I am studying Medical engineering at KTH in Stockholm, Sweden. I have just started my master thesis which is focused on FHIR and specifically the opportunities of FHIR profiling in Sweden. I will for example discuss profiles on a national level and profiles on more organizational levels. I came across the term tight and loose profiles. To me, a tight profile would be a profile which is very constricted and would be hard to create derived profiles from since there is not much room for more constrictions. My question is, does the terms tight and loose for describing profiles exist or are there other terms that would be better to use for this purpose?
These terms are not explicitly defined in the FHIR spec, but used informally. Sometimes I'll say "strict profile" vs "relaxed profile".
Is “looseness” or “tightness” measurable? If not, it is useless to talk about it.
You can certainly measure optionality/strictness by inspecting element cardinalities etc.
I don’t think so. Cardinality by itself isn’t looseness. It reflects how many things exist in the world, relative to other things.
I was thinking about e.g. counting elements constrained to 0...0 or 1...1 (removing optionality)
And some other attributes that we could measure.
But I agree, this is quite fuzzy and not a strict definition.
